captions.text:
It is a well-established fact that all truly 
great science fiction and fantasy begins with

a simple &quot;what if?&quot; scenario. &quot;What if you could 
travel through time?&quot; &quot;What if you could clone

dinosaurs?&quot; &quot;What if Jenny Agutter was running 
around, basically wearing nothing but green

tissue paper?&quot; And today&#39;s subject, Clair Obscur: 
Expedition 33, continues that fine tradition by

asking, &quot;What if once a year, a weird, giant, 
sad, naked lady in the sky painted a glowing

number on a mountain counting down from 100 and 
then everyone older than that number instantly

dies?&quot; Not the most concise elevator pitch, is it? 
I think the producer got off three stops ago. It

also posits the intriguing question &quot;What if 
a game had a title that was about as snappy

and comfortable in the mouth as a handful of 
drawing pins?&quot; as well as &quot;What if a traditional

turn-based JRPG was made by depressed, pretentious 
French artists?&quot; Sorry, that was a bit redundant,

wasn&#39;t it? Let me try again. What if a traditional 
turn-based JRPG was made by French artists? Well,

it&#39;ll still have broody, floppy-haired 
anime sword boys, but they&#39;ll all be

in their 30s with embarrassing moustaches 
and look uncannily like Robert Pattinson.

Anyway, the whole &quot;sad, naked lady counting down 
from 100&quot; age purge scenario described above is

happening to the last remnant of humanity in a 
French city cut off from the rest of a ruined,

monster-haunted world; presumably, no one gave 
much of a shit while it was still in the 80s

and 90s, but as the game starts, it&#39;s now gotten 
down to 33, and everyone&#39;s in a bit of a flap as

they&#39;re having to face the Logan&#39;s Run scenario 
without the consolation of Jenny Agutter&#39;s green

tissue paper dress. These garlic-munching twats 
are now facing the ultimate nightmare for French

people: having to get off their arses and do some 
bloody work. &quot;Are you racist against the French,

now, Yahtz?&quot; Excuse me, I&#39;m English. It&#39;s a little 
thing called cultural identity. And so, once a

year, they send an expedition of adventurers 
out into the world to confront the weird,

naked painter lady and give her a jolly good 
talking to. None of these expeditions have

ever returned, but there&#39;s no reason to assume 
that 66 failures represents a pattern, does it?

At least not if you&#39;ve been rendered blind by 
your necklace of onions making your eyes water.

Not that that&#39;s the only reason our eyes would 
be watering. Christ, this game&#39;s depressing. It

starts depressing with the prologue and the 
characters having to experience the purge

of the city&#39;s 34-year-olds, and as the game 
proper begins, works its way up to &quot;Google

keeps putting the number for suicide prevention 
lines under my YouTube streams.&quot; This game just

chomps at the fucking bit to murder established 
characters in front of you. The expedition reaches

its destination, and the protagonist has barely 
undone his fucking seatbelt before the carnage

begins, and all the friends that were patiently 
named and introduced throughout the prologue get

mowed down like it&#39;s the Wizard of Oz meets the 
Normandy Landings. The tiny handful of survivors

then resolve that they might as well see how far 
they can get before their hideous deaths, &#39;cause

it&#39;s either that or fucking doming themselves 
right now, and I guess that&#39;s one way to answer

the call to adventure. It might sound like I&#39;m 
talking shit, but I enjoyed the game&#39;s narrative

element, and not just because I like seeing French 
people die. There&#39;s some impressive creativity on

display in both the premise and the visuals. The 
story has some interesting turns and actually

has an explanation for why the game seems to be 
taking place inside a baroque surrealist painting.

But I&#39;m still kinda surprised the game&#39;s gotten 
such acclaim because the gameplay is like a sex

offender on public transport in that it rubs 
me up the wrong way in many uncomfortable

places. First time I entered a turn-based 
battle, my immediate thought was, &quot;Hang on,

this looks exactly like the Persona 5 battle 
interface, except with serifed fonts.&quot; Now,

that&#39;s not the problem. If you&#39;re booking a stay 
in JRPG town, there are much worse tour guides to

hire. But in Persona 5, the principles of combat 
are easy to grasp. Use thing what enemy weak to;

step two: win. In Clair Obscur, every party 
member you unlock has a bespoke set of rules

you have to get your head around. Each standard 
attack builds up perfection points that can then

be spent to make special attack C bestow the 
Defenseless status effect so that using special

attack D will put you into Virtuoso stance, 
which grants additional damage relative to

the enemy&#39;s number of bibbly bobblies as long 
as the knick-knack knocky is wing wong woggle

woggle woo woo. Jesus Christ, it&#39;s like playing 
the 52-pickup variant of Magic the Gathering.

On top of that, every party member can equip up 
to three Pictos, somehow—no idea what those are

or how they manifest physically; I&#39;m just going to 
assume they&#39;re different items of lingerie—which

grant passive buffs, and after a certain time, 
you learn those buffs and can equip them with

Lumina points; very Final Fantasy IX-y sort of 
system that makes the combat customizability

practically bottomless, but it wasn&#39;t long 
before I was constantly having to interrupt

my explorations to pause, apply upgrade points, 
and reassign my Pictos, and the last time I spent

this much time pissing around in shitty menus, 
I got thrown out of the Cheesecake Factory.

The menus aren&#39;t well designed, is the point. The 
interface navigation doesn&#39;t so much flow as flop

like a gasping fish on the floor of a rowboat. 
And the big joke is optimizing your stats and

buffs doesn&#39;t even matter much because every 
enemy attack in the game does no damage if you

time your dodges and parries right with the Paper 
Mario-style reaction system. Not that that&#39;s easy;

fucking hell, every single one of these hams 
feints and delays to throw off your timing.

Some moves you have to dodge; some you have to 
jump; some you parry; some you use the other,

special spicy parry with the little 
slowdown to really throw your timing off.

And when I say, &quot;have to,&quot; you do have to dodge 
as much damage as you can, especially when you can

get wiped out with one nine-hit combo that goes 
right past annoying and becomes actually quite

concerning, like, I worry the dude has unresolved 
trauma relating to people with attractive hairdos.

Still, once you have learned the timing, there&#39;s 
something satisfying about completely noping the

enemy attacks, and it means you don&#39;t have to 
fully engage with all the complicated optimization

mechanics, so I guess we can call that balance. 
My only other big issue with gameplay is that the

individual dungeons would seriously benefit from a 
map. Even a minimap. Or just a couple of big signs

saying, &quot;Hey, once you&#39;re done appreciating all 
the effort we put into the beautiful environment

design, this path over here leads to progress, and 
all these other identical paths lead to optional

shit.&quot; In very small text, obviously. So, after 
all that wibbling about with my gameplay issues

and lingering Francophobia from the Hundred 
Years&#39; War, in the end, the sheer creativity

on display means my thumb levels out to pointing 
upwards. Good game. Game good. Try game. Or,

as our beloved French cousins would say, &quot;S&#39;il 
vous plait envahissez-nous et volez tout notre
fromage.&quot;
